questions.text: Which of the following middle ear pathologies is most likely to cause maximum conductive hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Tympanosclerosis involving only the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Adhesive otitis media (Grade IV retraction pocket with atelectasis)

options.label: D
options.text: Otosclerosis with complete fixation of the stapes footplate

questions.correct_answer: C. Ossicular discontinuity involving incudostapedial joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity involving incudostapedial joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ossicular discontinuity causes maximum conductive hearing loss among middle ear pathologies due to complete disruption of sound transmission through the ossicular chain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic audiometric finding in noise-induced hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz

questions.correct_answer: B. Notch in audiogram at 4000 Hz
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Notch in audiogram at 4000 Hz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noise-induced hearing loss is classically associated with a 4000 Hz notch on pure tone audiometry.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss. He finds it difficult to follow conversations, especially in noisy environments. His pure tone audiogram is shown below. Identify the pattern of hearing loss shown in the audiogram:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Presbycusis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbycusis presents as a bilateral symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss on PTA with a gradual sloping pattern.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate fails the initial hearing screening test using Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE). What is the next appropriate step in audiological evaluation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Do BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Do BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In newborns who fail OAE screening, BERA is the next step to confirm hearing loss by assessing neural conduction objectively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss undergoes the following surgical procedure What is the procedure being performed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mastoidectomy involves drilling of mastoid air cells through a postauricular approach, typically for chronic ear infections or cholesteatoma.

questions.text: Which opening is located posterior to the marked structure in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sphenopalatine foramen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sphenopalatine foramen lies posterior to the middle turbinate and transmits the sphenopalatine artery into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss is being evaluated for cochlear implantation. Which of the following is the most important factor in determining the eligibility for cochlear implantation in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Auditory nerve integrity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most important factor in determining eligibility for cochlear implantation is the integrity of the auditory nerve, as a functional nerve is required for the implant to effectively transmit sound signals to the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes between the inferior and middle pharyngeal constrictors?

options.label: C
options.text: Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN)

questions.correct_answer: C. Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels pass between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent nasal obstruction, snoring, and a persistent, non-painful ear fullness. The child has a fluctuating conductive hearing loss but no signs of infection. On examination, the adenoids are visibly hypertrophied. What is the most appropriate management for this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Myringotomy with grommet insertion and adenoidectomy

questions.correct_answer: A. Myringotomy with grommet insertion and adenoidectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myringotomy with grommet insertion and adenoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with Otitis Media with Effusion (OME) caused by hypertrophied adenoids, the treatment of choice is myringotomy with grommet insertion and adenoidectomy.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of sneezing, nasal obstruction, and watery rhinorrhea especially in the morning. He frequently rubs his nose in an upward manner, and has dark circles under his eyes. On anterior rhinoscopy, the nasal mucosa appears pale and boggy. His serum IgE is elevated. Despite oral antihistamines and intranasal steroids, he remains symptomatic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Initiate anti-IgE monoclonal antibody therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Initiate anti-IgE monoclonal antibody therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omalizumab (anti-IgE) is indicated in severe allergic rhinitis refractory to conventional therapy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with chronic mouth breathing, snoring, and recurrent episodes of earache. On examination, he has a high-arched palate, crowded teeth, and a dull facial appearance. Which of the following is the most likely underlying anatomical cause for his recurrent ear symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Obstruction of Eustachian tube by enlarged adenoids

options.label: C
options.text: Infection spreading from tonsillar crypts to middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: Reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions into the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: A. Obstruction of Eustachian tube by enlarged adenoids
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Obstruction of Eustachian tube by enlarged adenoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enlarged adenoids can obstruct Eustachian tube openings, leading to serous otitis media in children.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction for the past few months. His mother also reports a gradual swelling on one side of his cheek and bulging of his left eye. On examination, a red, fleshy mass is visible in the nasal cavity. CT scan shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnostic nasal biopsy under local anesthesia

options.label: B
options.text: Start oral antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: D
options.text: Radiotherapy to shrink the vascular tumor

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical planning with imaging studies
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Surgical planning with imaging studies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with epistaxis and nasal obstruction in adolescent males and is managed with surgical excision guided by imaging; biopsy is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from Southeast Asia presents with a 3-month history of painless neck swelling and recent onset of nasal obstruction and decreased hearing in the right ear. He also reports denasal speech. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender level II cervical lymph node on the right side. Otoscopy reveals a retracted tympanic membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Tubercular lymphadenitis with middle ear effusion

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic allergic rhinitis with adenoidal hypertrophy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and unilateral conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe sore throat, high-grade fever, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice. He also reports pain while opening his mouth. On examination, there is trismus, medial displacement of the right tonsil, and deviation of the uvula to the left. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and drainage of the abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Biopsy of the tonsil to rule out malignancy

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and drainage of the abscess
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage of the abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess is treated with incision and drainage followed by antibiotics and interval tonsillectomy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoes surgery for cholesteatoma of the middle ear. The ENT surgeon explains that the chosen approach involves preservation of the posterior canal wall, allowing the patient to swim and use a hearing aid without difficulty, but it may require a second surgery in 6 months. Which of the following best describes this surgical approach?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Canal-wall-up mastoidectomy preserves canal anatomy and allows swimming and hearing aid use, but carries a higher recurrence risk and often requires second-look surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with long-standing chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents with vertigo on tragal pressure. On otoscopic examination, attic cholesteatoma is seen. Which of the following best explains the positive fistula test in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Perilymphatic fistula due to lateral semicircular canal erosion

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrous attachment between membranous labyrinth and footplate

options.label: D
options.text: Dead labyrinth due to longstanding cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Perilymphatic fistula due to lateral semicircular canal erosion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perilymphatic fistula due to lateral semicircular canal erosion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cholesteatoma, erosion of the lateral semicircular canal causes a true perilymph fistula, detected by a positive fistula sign.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with a history of chronic ear discharge now presents with high-grade fever with chills and rigors, which subsides with sweating. On examination, he has edema over the posterior part of the mastoid region. Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis presents with picket-fence fever, Greisinger’s sign, papilledema, and is confirmed by raised intracranial tension and delta sign on imaging.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of chronic nasal crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and progressive loss of smell. On anterior rhinoscopy, the nasal cavity appears roomy with pale mucosa and crusts adherent to the turbinates. She does not perceive the bad odor emanating from her own nose. Which of the following best explains this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Involvement of olfactory bulb due to chronic infection

options.label: B
options.text: Merciful anosmia due to atrophy of olfactory nerve endings

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction of nasal passages by hypertrophied turbinates

options.label: D
options.text: Ciliary hypertrophy due to chronic irritation

questions.correct_answer: B. Merciful anosmia due to atrophy of olfactory nerve endings
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Merciful anosmia due to atrophy of olfactory nerve endings

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis causes anosmia due to sensory nerve atrophy, sparing the patient from perceiving their own foul nasal discharge — termed "merciful anosmia."

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents with severe ear pain for 2 weeks and foul-smelling ear discharge. On otoscopic examination, granulation tissue is noted in the external auditory canal. He now has right-sided facial weakness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malignant otitis externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is a Pseudomonas infection of the external auditory canal in diabetics, causing severe pain, granulations, and possible facial palsy with skull base involvement.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with gradually progressive hearing loss, which improves in noisy surroundings. Otoscopy reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a reddish hue over the promontory. Audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis presents with conductive hearing loss, Carhart’s notch, intact tympanic membrane, and Schwartz sign in young adults, especially females.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent brief episodes of vertigo that are triggered when he turns his head to the right while lying down. The episodes last for less than a minute and are not associated with hearing loss or tinnitus. Dix-Hallpike test is positive. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism?

options.label: B
options.text: Dislodgement of otoconia from utricle into posterior semicircular canal

options.label: D
options.text: Lesion in cerebellar flocculus causing central vertigo

questions.correct_answer: B. Dislodgement of otoconia from utricle into posterior semicircular canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dislodgement of otoconia from utricle into posterior semicircular canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BPPV is caused by dislodgement of otoconia from the utricle into the posterior semicircular canal, leading to brief positional vertigo.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo lasting several hours, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of aural fullness. Otoscopy is normal, and audiometry shows low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Electrocochleography shows SP/AP ratio > 0.3. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vestibular sedatives and diuretics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease is initially managed with vestibular sedatives and diuretics to reduce endolymphatic pressure and control vertigo.

questions.text: A lesion selectively affecting the posteroinferior quadrant of the internal auditory canal will most likely involve which of the following nerve components?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior vestibular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior vestibular nerve occupies the posteroinferior quadrant of the internal auditory canal and innervates the saccule and posterior semicircular canal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with gradually progressive unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Audiometry shows high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. MRI with gadolinium contrast reveals a cerebellopontine angle mass. Which of the following additional findings most strongly suggests a retrocochlear pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of recruitment and high SISI score

options.label: B
options.text: Normal BERA and preserved stapedial reflex

options.label: C
options.text: Poor speech discrimination with absent stapedial reflex and abnormal BERA

options.label: D
options.text: Improved hearing in noisy surroundings (Paracusis Willisii)

questions.correct_answer: C. Poor speech discrimination with absent stapedial reflex and abnormal BERA
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Poor speech discrimination with absent stapedial reflex and abnormal BERA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acoustic neuroma causes poor speech discrimination, absent stapedial reflex, and abnormal BERA—hallmarks of retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presents with sudden-onset facial asymmetry, inability to close her left eye, drooling from the corner of her mouth, and hypersensitivity to loud sounds. Examination shows Bell’s phenomenon on attempted eye closure. Otoscopy is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical decompression of the facial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Observation only, as it is self-limiting

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral prednisolone with acyclovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bell’s palsy is treated with early administration of prednisolone and acyclovir to reduce nerve inflammation and improve recovery.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital sensorineural hearing loss. Imaging reveals complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinths. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Michel aplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Michel aplasia is the most severe congenital hearing defect, characterized by complete absence of both bony and membranous labyrinths.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of low-grade fever, hoarseness, and a barking cough. On examination, he has inspiratory stridor and intercostal retractions. A neck X-ray shows a tapering of the upper trachea resembling a steeple. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup presents in young children with barking cough, stridor, and steeple sign on neck X-ray, most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the pediatric larynx is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The larynx in children is positioned lower in the neck than in adults

options.label: B
options.text: The epiglottis in infants is leaf-shaped and rigid

options.label: C
options.text: The narrowest part of the pediatric airway is the glottis

options.label: D
options.text: The pediatric larynx has a conical shape with the narrowest portion at the subglottis

questions.correct_answer: D. The pediatric larynx has a conical shape with the narrowest portion at the subglottis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The pediatric larynx has a conical shape with the narrowest portion at the subglottic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pediatric larynx is funnel-shaped with the narrowest portion at the subglottis, making airway edema more clinically significant.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when crying and improves when lying prone. On flexible laryngoscopy, an omega-shaped epiglottis and collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration are seen. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Observation and reassurance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants and is usually managed by observation, as it resolves spontaneously by 2 years.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male chronic smoker presents with a 2-month history of hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, a lesion is seen involving the vocal cords. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a poor prognosis due to early lymphatic spread

options.label: B
options.text: It is usually diagnosed late due to lack of symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: It has better prognosis because of early presentation and limited lymphatic spread

options.label: D
options.text: It most commonly presents with stridor due to airway narrowing

questions.correct_answer: C. It has better prognosis because of early presentation and limited lymphatic spread
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It has better prognosis because of early presentation and limited lymphatic spread

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glottic carcinoma presents early with hoarseness and has better prognosis due to limited lymphatic spread and early diagnosis.

questions.text: A surgical microscope is being set up for a stapedectomy. Which of the following focal lengths is most appropriate for optimal visualization during this ear surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 200 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For ENT microscopic surgeries, focal lengths used are 200 mm for ear, 300 mm for nose, and 400 mm for throat procedures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with recurrent pus discharge from a small pit located just anterior to the external ear. Examination reveals a sinus opening in the preauricular region. What is the most likely embryological basis for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches

options.label: B
options.text: Malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal clefts

options.label: C
options.text: Malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouches

options.label: D
options.text: Overlapping of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches

questions.correct_answer: A. Malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is a congenital anomaly caused by malfusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, often presenting with recurrent infections near the external ear.

questions.text: A patient undergoes a Rinne test with different tuning forks to assess hearing loss. The patient shows a negative Rinne test at 256Hz, a negative result at 512Hz, but a positive Rinne test at 1024Hz. Based on this, what is the approximate degree of hearing loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 30-45 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative Rinne test at 256Hz and 512Hz but a positive Rinne at 1024Hz corresponds to an approximate hearing loss of 30-45 dB.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of difficulty hearing during conversations, especially when speaking with family members in a normal setting. His hearing difficulty is less pronounced when someone speaks loudly, but he often struggles with whispers. Based on this information, what is the patient's approximate hearing threshold?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 30-60 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hearing loss in the range of 30-60 dB typically causes difficulty with normal conversation but may still allow the patient to hear loud voices or shouts.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram in the provided image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Meniere’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease typically presents with low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss on audiogram, differentiating it from other conditions like otosclerosis (2 kHz dip), NIHL (4 kHz dip), and acoustic neuroma (trough-shaped loss).

questions.text: Identify the following sequence of otoendoscopic images from left to right.

options.label: A
options.text: Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum

options.label: B
options.text: Serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum, Glomus tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Glomus tumor, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum, serous otitis media

options.label: D
options.text: Normal eardrum, Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)

questions.correct_answer: A. Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), normal eardrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Be able to differentiate common otoendoscopic findings such as glomus tumor, serous otitis media, chronic suppurative otitis media, and a normal eardrum based on characteristic tympanic membrane appearances.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II tympanoplasty places a graft on the incus or remnant of the malleus, Type III on the stapes (columella tympanoplasty), Type IV on the stapes footplate (cavum minor), and Type V involves a fenestration operation.

questions.text: Mark the false statement/statements regarding Inner and Outer hair cells: Outer hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate the function of outer hair cells. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio of 1:3 respectively.

options.label: A
options.text: I, III, and IV are false

options.label: B
options.text: I, II, and III are false

questions.correct_answer: A. I, III, and IV are false
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) I, III, and IV are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Outer hair cells, arranged in 3–4 rows, modulate the function of inner hair cells, which are arranged in a single row and transmit auditory signals to the brain.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of the auditory pathway: Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is: spiral ganglion → cochlear nucleus → superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body.

questions.text: A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry is given. Pick the correct combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: B
options.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

options.label: C
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of right-sided sensorineural hearing loss , both ears will show a positive Rinne's test , and Weber's test will lateralize to the left ear (the better hearing ear).
  • ➤ right-sided sensorineural hearing loss
  • ➤ positive Rinne's test
  • ➤ Weber's test will lateralize to the left ear

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Ad tympanogram seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ossicular dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Type Ad tympanogram is seen in conditions with increased compliance of the tympanic membrane, such as ossicular dislocation .
  • ➤ Type Ad tympanogram
  • ➤ ossicular dislocation

questions.text: Identify the otoendoscopy image. The black-headed spores in this image indicate which organism growth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger otomycosis presents with black-headed spores in otoendoscopy, which are a hallmark of this fungal infection in the external auditory canal.
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger
  • ➤ black-headed spores

questions.text: Type of perforation seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subtotal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A subtotal perforation involves a large portion of the tympanic membrane, sparing the margins, and is more extensive than central perforations.
  • ➤ subtotal perforation

questions.text: Which of the following does not require immediate surgical intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasal bone fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasal bone fractures usually do not require immediate surgical intervention and can often be delayed for up to a week to allow swelling to subside before performing the necessary reduction.
  • ➤ Nasal bone fractures

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with profuse epistaxis. Initial nasal packing fails to control the bleeding. Surgical ligation of the sphenopalatine and maxillary arteries is performed, but the patient continues to bleed. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Ligation of external carotid artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ligation of external carotid artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If epistaxis persists despite sphenopalatine and maxillary artery ligation, the next step is ligation of the external carotid artery.

questions.text: In which radiographic view is the sphenoid sinus best visualized?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pierre view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pierre view is the radiographic view in which the sphenoid sinus is best visualized.
  • ➤ Pierre view
  • ➤ sphenoid sinus

questions.text: All of the following are related to CSF rhinorrhea except:

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards

questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral watery nasal discharge on bending forwards

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea typically presents with unilateral watery nasal discharge , often worsening on bending forward, and is commonly associated with trauma, halo sign, and managed with antibiotics and acetazolamide.
  • ➤ unilateral watery nasal discharge

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. During examination, it is noted that her vocal cords are paralyzed on both sides. Which nerve is most likely damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)

options.label: B
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN)

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) supplies all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid and is most likely damaged during thyroid surgeries, leading to vocal cord paralysis and hoarseness .
  • ➤ recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
  • ➤ vocal cord paralysis and hoarseness

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of lesions in the larynx:

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal granuloma, reinke oedema, vocal cyst

options.label: B
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal cyst

options.label: C
options.text: Leukoplakia, vocal cancer, polypoid corditis, vocal polyp

options.label: D
options.text: Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal polyp

questions.correct_answer: D. Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, reinke oedema, vocal polyp
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vocal nodule, vocal cancer, Reinke’s edema, vocal polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of laryngeal lesions progresses from vocal nodules (benign) to vocal cancer (malignant) , followed by Reinke’s edema (benign fluid accumulation) , and finally vocal polyps (benign lesions due to trauma) .
  • ➤ vocal nodules (benign)
  • ➤ vocal cancer (malignant)
  • ➤ Reinke’s edema (benign fluid accumulation)
  • ➤ vocal polyps (benign lesions due to trauma)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with unilateral hearing loss. Oto-endoscopic picture is shown below. Rinne was negative and weber lateralised to the same ear. Clinically next structure to be observed in the patient is
questions.explanation:
Ans. D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unilateral serous otitis media in older adults, especially with conductive hearing loss, nasopharyngeal pathology (like nasopharyngeal carcinoma) should be ruled out with nasopharyngeal endoscopy.
  • ➤ unilateral serous otitis media
  • ➤ nasopharyngeal pathology
